awd_titl_txt: A 750,000-yr Leaf Wax Biomarker Record to Assess Environmental Change Across the Plio-Pleistocene Boundary in Tropical East Africa
awd_abstract_narration:
About three million years ago, the Arctic cooled dramatically, and northern hemisphere glaciers expanded and began to wax and wane in 41,000-year glacial cycles.  Around the same time, parts of Africa became drier, and our human ancestors underwent a set of evolutionary shifts including the appearance of the genus Homo.  Many studies have suggested that these changes are linked, wherein global cooling causes drying over Africa, which in turn triggers human evolutionary responses.  This project will reconstruct environmental changes occurring in Africa between 3.3 and 2.5 million years ago to test the relationships between global climate transitions, African environmental change, and human evolutionary events.  This research will provide an outstanding platform to train a diverse set of students and young researchers in interdisciplinary research in the Earth Sciences, including Brown University graduate students and undergraduate students from historically underrepresented groups.  We will further develop new middle-school educational modules on environmental change and human evolution in collaboration with teachers from the Providence public schools.

This project aims to develop new, high-resolution records of African environmental change through organic geochemical analyses of a recently recovered, exceptionally well-dated ~750,000-year-long drill core from the Baringo-Tugen-Barsemoi (BTB), in the Eastern Kenyan Rift that spans the Plio-Pleistocene boundary.  We will analyze the hydrogen and carbon isotopic composition of terrestrial leaf wax biomarkers in this core to detect changes in rainfall and vegetation between 3.3 and 2.55 Ma. These data will be used to test the relationships between East African climate and vegetation and the onset and intensification of northern hemisphere glaciation, as well as other global and regional climate forcings.  Our new data will be further compared to mammalian and hominin fossil datasets to test whether changes in the trend, variability, and rate of environmental change can be related to hominin evolutionary events.  These state-of-the-art analyses will provide research training opportunities for a diverse set of graduate and undergraduate students and provide a framework to develop new middle-school educational modules on environmental change and human evolution that meet Next Generation Science Standards. Project results will refine our understanding of the connections between high and low latitude climate and the impacts of long-term vs. orbital-scale changes in global climate on African climate, ecosystems, and hominin evolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the role of environmental change in the evolution of our species is an enduring scientific challenge. Over a century ago, anthropologists hypothesized that continental-scale drying in Africa caused forests to contract and grasslands to expand, forcing Hominids (primates including humans and their ancestors) to adapt to a more open and drier environment. More recently, scientists hypothesized that a more variable environment selected for generalist traits in our Hominid ancestors, allowing them to inhabit a range of environments and climates. Testing these hypotheses and understanding the mechanisms and controls on long-term climate change in Africa requires long and highly resolved records of climate and environmental change from the sites and basins in which our human ancestors lived – records that have proven difficult to obtain. To this end, this project developed records of environmental change from the Baringo-Tugen Hills Basin (BTB), located near the equator in Kenya. BTB is well known for its Hominid records, including the first appearance of the genus Homo (the human genus) 2.8 million years ago. This timing, close to the timing of the appearance of large ice sheets in the Arctic, suggests links between human evolution and climate. 

To evaluate these hypotheses, we developed records of rainfall and vegetation based on the hydrogen and carbon isotopic composition of leaf waxes preserved in drill cores from BTB that cover the period from 3.3 to 2.6 million years ago (Ma). Our data, analyzed at a 3,000-year resolution, allow us to investigate both long-term changes in vegetation and rainfall, as well as changes happening at glacial-interglacial timescales. We found that a) in contrast to parts of North Africa and conventional theory, the BTB area became wetter, not drier at ~3.0 Ma; b) rainfall shows pronounced 41,000-year cycles through this time interval, and these cycles intensified after 3.0 Ma, c) grasslands expanded at ~3.0 Ma, despite the transition to a generally wetter climate. Through comparison to other tropical records, we show that the onset of wetter conditions can be linked to high-latitude cooling and adjustments of temperature gradients in the tropical Indian Ocean; the 41,000-year cycles in rainfall can be linked to cross-equatorial insolation gradients and/or high-latitude glacial cycles; the expansion of grasslands at 3.0 Ma results from a intensified precipitation seasonality, and in particular a longer and/or drier dry season. Overall, these results point to considerable spatiotemporal heterogeneity in African climates and environments, particularly after 3.0 Ma, in support of the hypothesis that environmental variability influenced Hominin evolution. 

Our results were presented at numerous national and international scientific conferences and are described in six peer-reviewed publications and two Ph.D. dissertations. In addition to our scientific outcomes, this project provided interdisciplinary scientific training for five undergraduate students and two Ph.D. students who have gone on to careers in the scientific workforce. Project participants developed and implemented a two-week summer course for high school students on human evolution, archaeology, and environmental change. Several of the students in the project also participated in outreach programs to develop lesson plans for science education in elementary schools in the Providence Public School System and programs to educate high school juniors and seniors about careers in the Earth Sciences.
